div3.p: Official returns from all but five counties in Alabama of the vote cast for Delegates to the State Convention, show the following result, viz:

Compared with the Presidential, the falling off in the aggregate vote is about 22,000, which amount, of course, is reduced by the returns from the five counties not heard from.
The secessionists claim that their majority would have been increased by the increased vote. --Nor is it reasonable to conclude that co-operationists are not secessionists.
They were most of them in favor of seceding when four States had seceded.
But Alabama makes the fourth out of the Union, and so the co-operationists have not much to complain of.

div3.head: A just Rebuke.
div3.p:
The valiant offer of Major Gen. Sandford, of the 1st Division of New York Militia, for the purpose of whipping the South, is respectfully declined by many of the best and bravest of its officers and men. (See another column.) The Major General will find that he cannot transfer the gallant soldiers of N. York like cattle.
There is not, by any manner of means, to be a united North in this bloody business of coercion.
A large working men's meeting, the bone and muscle of the Empire City, have indignantly denounced the idea; and in Philadelphia, at an enthusiastic assembly of whole souled patriots, they declared that in the event of Disunion they would go with the South.
A coercionist present, who attempted to disturb the proceedings, was himself "coerced " out of the window.

div3.head: The right of secession — the power of coercion in the Federal Government.
div3.p:
We invoke earnestly the attention of our readers to a communication on these subjects which we transfer to our columns from the Baltimore Sun.
Let them read carefully the irresistible authorities there collected upon the subject.
Let them see how all parties, in the formation of the Constitution, including Alexander Hamilton, arrayed themselves against those despotic and monstrous doctrines and pretensions now put forth by the Republicans.

div3.head: A Confessed Perjurer.
div3.p: The N. Y. Evening Post says:

q.p: "A Republican who has just returned from Maryland, reports that ten thousand men have been secretly organized in Mary land and Virginia, to prevent the inauguration of Lincoln, and to stop all progress through the State to the Federal Capital.
"He says that he traveled as a Virginian, and gained the confidence of the conspirators by taking the oath of secrecy."
Who can believe a man that confesses himself a hypocrite and perjurer?

There is no truth in his base charge.
It is a wicked invention of the Republicans to justify the meditated incursion of the "Wide Awakes" into Washington,

div3.head: Lincoln speaks again.
div3.p:
By reference to the extracts on our first page on the crisis, it will be seen that the Tribune, Lincoln's oracle, speaks by authority for him that he will make no consessions whatever.
Seward, in his polished and artful generalities, had already indicated as much.

div3.head: The Slaves.
div3.p: The Charleston correspondent of the Baltimore American gives a graphic picture (which will be found on our first page) of the faithful Carolina servants going to fight "de dam Abumlishnists."

div3.head: Rich Copper ore.
div3.p:
The Senator from Grayson, &c., Col. McCamant, has deposited in our office a very rich specimen — sulphuret — of copper ore from the Peach Bottom Mines, of his district.
The copper deposit of that region is exceedingly rich and very extensive.
It promises great wealth to those who may operate it with that prudence taught by experience.

div3.head: Lincoln's Journey to Washington.
div3.p: --The Marshal of the Police Department of Baltimore has written to the Mayor of Washington that the "President elect" is in no danger of an attack while passing through the Monumental City, on his way to the seat of Government." The "President elect," he says, "will need no armed escort in passing through or sojourning within the limits of this city or State, and, in my view, the provision of any such at this time would be ill-judged." The mind of the "President elect" will doubtless be relieved by this assurance.

div3.head: Payment of duties in seceding States.
div3.p: --A Washington dispatch says that the Secretary of State has informed Lord Lyons and other Foreign Ministers that no clearances of vessels issued by any other authority than the United States officials will be recognized, and that any payments of duties on imports, except to such officials, will be regarded as mispayments, for which the parties paying will be held responsible to our Government.

div3.head: From California.
div3.p:
--By the arrival of the Pony express at Fort Kearney on the 16th inst., we have San Francisco advices to the 2d inst.
The news should have reached us earlier, but owing to a heavy storm in the vicinity of Fort Kearney, the dispatches have been unavoidably delayed.
The important item is the departure of the steamer Golden Age, with $1,265,000 in treasure, for New York.
Among the passengers is Col. Fremont.

div3.head: Reaction.
div3.p: --The conservative citizens of Rome, N. Y., on Thursday evening resolved not to permit the band of Abolitionists which has been roaming about the western part of that State to indulge in their antics, and accordingly took possession of the place of meeting, and prevented all speaking.

div3.head: Arrival of specie.
div3.p: --The Edinburgh, from Europe, arrived at New York Thursday night, brings £106,000 --$530,000--and the Canadian, at Portland, $65,000. The Teutonia, boarded off Cape Race, Wednesday, en route for New York, has $333,000. The Asia also brings $1,500,000 in specie.

div3.head: Convention called.
div3.p: --The New York Democratic State Committee, in view of the alarming condition of the country, have issued a call for an election of four delegates in each Assembly district, to hold a State Convention at Albany on the 31st of January.

div3.head: A Washington rumor.
div3.p: --There is a rumor in "high political circles," at Washington, that South Carolina intends storming Fort Sumter, and calculates upon a loss of many hundreds of lives.

div3.head: Old Relic gone.
div3.p: --The house in which Thomas Jefferson was born, at Shadwell Depot, in the county of Albemarle, Va., was burned on Thursday night.

div3.head: Commodore Shubrick.
div3.p:
--The announcement of the death of Commodore Shubrick, U. S. N., at Pendleton, S. C., was erroneous.
He is in Washington, attending to business.

div3.head: Newspaper change.
div3.p: --Mr. Wm. F. Gordon, Jr., has assumed the proprietorship of the Clarksburg (Va.) Register, Mr. W. P. Cooper having retired.

div3.head: Burnt to Death.
div3.p: --An elderly lady named Sarah Jarboe, who lived alone, in St. Mary's county, Md., was so severely burnt on Saturday night week, that she died the succeeding day.

div3.head: Hon. H. A. Wise,
div3.p: of Princess Anne county, is a candidate for the State Convention.
A company called the Home Guard is organizing in Westmoreland co., Va.
At Williamsburg, Va., on Monday, there was sufficient hail to cover the ground.
Samuel Gilford, an old and prominent merchant of New York, died on the 16th inst.
Senator A. G. Brown, of Miss., has gone home.

div3.head:
Legal and Insurance Reporter, 424 Walnut street, Philadelphia.
extra.
Ballooning of another Insurance Co.
the Quaker city gone up!
div3.p:
Philadelphia, Jan. 15, 1861. --In our last number, in speaking of the State Saving Fund having gone into liquidation, we stated that there were one or two insurance Companies of our city so intimately connected with that institution, that its ruin involved theirs.
Since then our fears have been in a measure realized.
The Quaker City Insurance Company, one of those referred to, has this day resolved to go into liquidation, and accordingly made an assignment to Seth H. Butler, the Assistant Secretary.
The reason given for this movement is, that during the past year the Company has met with a series of reverses, and paid losses amounting to over a quarter of a million dollars. Apart from the absurdity of this statement, it is even insufficient in itself.
What has become of the component parts of the Company's list of securities, as set forth in their last annual statement, as follows:

row.cell: Bonds and Mortgages on Real Estate
15 Shares Farmers' and Mechanics' Bank, Camden, New Jersey
2030 Shares of Railroad, Canal and other Stocks, all paying 6 per cent., market value
Coupon Bonds, bearing 6 and 7 per cent
Cash in hands of agents and in transit
Cash on hand and in bank

div3.p: Officers:
George H. Hart, President.
E. P. Ross, Vice President.
H. R. Coggshall, Sec'y and Treas'r.
S. H. Butler, Assistant Secretary.
Hon. Henry M. Fuller.
H. R. Coggshall, Secretary;

If this was truthful, then, even with the alleged loss, there was no reason for the present failure.
But the true cause is not given, but is to be found in the fact that many of these assets have not, and never had, the value pretended.
The Company has all along done business on a false and unsubstantial base, and its present ruin will reveal the fact.
We take some credit to ourselves that notwithstanding the alleged good condition and the frequent efforts made by the Company to obtain a place in our advertising columns, they never obtained any such endorsement of their reliability.
Repeatedly were these efforts made; but our rule, requiring a verification of the statements before publishing them, was inflexibly enforced, and we feel a just pride that by no act of ours has the community been made to suffer.
Other Insurance papers had less scruples.

The present assets and liabilities of the concern is a mystery.
Particulars will be given as ascertained, in regular issues of the "Reporter."

div3.head: Married.
div3.p: In Lynchburg, Va., on the 17th inst., by the Rev. Mr. Mitchell, of the Centenary Church, Mr. Geo. W. Donley, of Richmond, Va., and Miss Addie E. Mauck, of the former place.
Schr. Emma Jane, Phillips, for Richmond, cl'd at Baltimore 18th inst.
Schr. M. H. Read, Kelley, from Norfolk for New Bedford, arrived at New York 18th inst.
Schr. Sailie Mears (of Yorktown, Va.), Richardson, Antigua, Dec. 23, via St. Martins 28th, with salt, arrived at New York 18th inst.

Schr. Frances, O'Dounell, for Norfolk, cleared at New York 19th inst.
Schrs. Crenshaw, Moss, Richmond; S. C. Jones, Bedell, Norfolk; and Margaret, Henson, City Point, arrived at do. same day.
Schr. Problem, Jones, from Richmond, arrived at Norfolk 18th inst.
Ocean Breeze, Leighton, from Alexandria, arrived at Gibraltar 21st ult.
New York, Cooper, from Richmond, arrived at Marseilles 27th ult.
Disaseer.

Br. bark Jane Brown, Broose, 8 days from Richmond, Va., bound to Liverpool, with a cargo of wheat and flour, experienced a heavy gale on the 26th Dec., was thrown on her beam ends and became very leaky, and was obliged to bear up for Bermuda, where she arrived about the 1st inst.

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p: --An adjourned meeting of the Stockholders of the James River and Kanawha Company will be held at the Company's Office, in the city of Richmond, on Monday, the 28th January, 1861, at 7½ o'clock P. M.
appointment of Proxy.

Know all men by these presents: That we, the subscribers, being Stockholders in the James River and Kanawha Company, do hereby constitute and appoint -- our true and lawful Attorney and Proxy, to represent each of us in all general meetings of the Stockholders of said Company, held within six months from and after the date hereof, when we are not personally present or represented by some other Proxy; with full power and authority at such general meetings to give such vote or votes and to do such other act or acts as each of us could give or do as a member of the said meetings, if we were personally present; and we do hereby ratify and confirm whatever vote or votes, act or acts, our said Attorney may lawfully give or do for us, in pursuance of the authority hereby conferred upon him.
Witness our hands and seals this -- day of --, one thousand eight hundred and --.
ja 21--eodtd Wm. P. Munford, Sec'y.

div3.head: Members of the Jefferson Debating Society
div3.p: are requested to meet this Evening, at 7 o'clock, at their Hall, in Winfree's School-House, corner Broad and 20th streets. A full attendance is desired, as business of importance will be presented.
ja 21--1t C. C. Folkes, Pres't.

div3.head: Company "B," 1st Reg't Va. Volunteers.
div3.p:
--An Adjourned meeting will be held at the city Hall, on Tuesday Evening, the 22d inst., at 7½ o'clk.
Those disposed to unite with the Company are requested to be present.
There is every reason to believe that the corps will speedily be organized, and if a sufficient number be enrolled, the organization may be perfected at this meeting.
Jamse K. Lee. Committee.
J. F. C. Lotts. Committee.

div3.head: For Baltimore.
div3.p: --The Steamer Belvidere, Capt.W. W. Keene, will receive Freight to-day, (Monday,) and up to the hour of 12 o'clock M., Tuesday, the 22d January.
Freight taken to Boston, via Baltimore, at lowest rates, with great dispatch.
No Hogsheads received on board unless engaged at our office.
Passengers are requested to be on board before the hour of departure, 12 o'clock M., Tuesday.
Passage and Fare $5.

Tickets procured either at our office, in Shockoe Slip, opposite the Columbian Hotel, or at steamers' wharves.
David & Wm. Currie.
--for New York via Norfolk.--The Roanoke, Captain Geo. W. Couch, will leave here at 4 o'clock P. M., Tuesday, the 22d inst.
Passengers are requested to be on board in due time.
Passage to New York, meals and state-room included, $10. Steerage passage only $5.
Freight received to-day, (Monday,) and up to the hour of 1 o'clock P. M., Tuesday.
Consignees are requested to send for their goods to-day.
Tickets and berths secured at our office, or on board the ship.
Freight for Boston taken at moderate rates and forwarded with dispatch.
ja 21--2t Ludlam & Watson.

--The A No. 1 Steamship Virginia, Captain Kelley, is now ready to receive freight.
Due notice will be given of her departure.
For further information, apply to

div3.head: For sale or Rent
div3.p:
--The excellent Brick Tenement, on the north side of Canal, between 1st and 2d sts., now in the occupancy of Alex. H. Sands, Esq. It has 10 rooms, besides brick kitchen, brick stable and carriage-house.
The premises are supplied with gas and water.
Possession given 1st February next.
Apply to [ja 21--3t]Goddin & Apperson.

div3.p:
--The desirable Dwelling-House on the south side of Grace, between 3d and 4th streets, adjoining the residence of Mr. Wm. Breeden, and belonging to the estate of A. V. Crenshaw, dec'd. Possession given 1st of March next.

div3.head:
Messrs. J. R. Humphreys.
Higgins and others.
div3.p:
--Dear Sirs: In answer to numerous applications and inquiries made in relation to my being a candidate for the ensuing Convention, I beg leave to state, very frankly, that I have no particular desire for a seat in the Convention.
The arduous duties and responsible trusts necessarily resulting from such a position may well challenge the solicitude of the ablest and most experienced men of our city.
I should distrust my own abilities; nevertheless.
I do not feel at liberty, under existing circumstances, to withhold the use of my name from those of my friends who have approached me on the subject: under the distinct proviso, however, that I cannot consent to its use at the risk of discord, engendered by individual rivalries, among the conservative men of Richmond.

The exigencies of the times demand the utmost practical harmony among the conservative men of this city.
If we are to hope for success, we must be united, conciliatory and firm.
The least discord in our ranks will ensure success to the precipitating revolutionists.
Any man who, for the purposes of mere personal aggrandizement, could seek individual advancement in such times as these, at even the slightest hazard of a united and successful effort to maintain the proper conservatism on which all well regulated governments eventually depend, is, in my opinion, unworthy of the confidence of the people.
Patriotism should yield everything but honor a willing sacrifice to the preservation of the constitutional rights of the people, and the preservation of the Union.
This I am fully prepared to do, whether as a private citizen or in a public station.

As to my views on the pending issues of the day, I have no concealments to make.
My honest convictions are my own property, and will not be yielded for all the honors and preferment at the disposal of the people.
My views on the subject of the policy of Virginia, at this time, were fully expressed in Huntsville, Alabama, in a discussion with a Breckinridge Elector, last September.
I give you the following extract:

div4.head: From the Huntsville (Ala.) advocated, of Sept. 26, 1860.]
div4.p:
"Mr. John H. Gilmer, in substance said, he felt called upon, here, before this audience, and in the presence of the friends of the Hon. Wm. L. Yancey, to repel the imputations and insinuations against Virginia, contained in the letter of Mr. Yancey, written in 1858, to R. A. Rryor, Esq., in explanation of the famous Slaughter letter.
Virginia is my mother, and I am proud of her past history, and the glories which cluster around her revolutionary memories.
Her people are slow to act, but powerful in their action; just in their discriminations, but resolute in their resolves.--Patient, thoughtful, patriotic — they are as brave as the bravest — and when real dangers threaten the institutions of the South, come from what quarter, or in what form they may, Virginia would proudly and nobly illustrate the patriotic action of her great leaders of revolutionary memory. --But she was a Union--loving, law-abiding State. --While her partisan leaders might fret, and chafe, and appeal to the passions and prejudices of her people, there was an innate love of justice, civil and social rights in the hearts of the people of Virginia which rendered them, individually and collectively, impervious to the sectional appeals of the disunionist, as well as the maddened frenzy of the Abolitionist.
Steady in the line of her general policy, in relation to our Federal system of Government, she persistently resisted the aggressive measures of the Black Republicans, while she held in serene contempt the blustering policy of the avowed secessionists.

"Her policy-- inculcated by the staid virtures and matured principles of her people — was as fixed as it was patriotic, as firm as it was well selected.-- She was for fighting all the battles of the South in the Union and under the Constitution. Yes, Alabamians, I here proclaim to you, for and on behalf of Virginia, that she is too brave to retreat in the face of an approaching foe. She regards secession as a run away remedy, to be resorted to only by the timid, the selfish, or those who desire a pretext for a dissolution of this glorious Union. Virginia will never turn her back upon an advancing foe. She has a noble heritage, in this Union, far too valuable to be idly and wantonly thrown away.--She is ready to sacrifice all but her honor, under the Constitution, in defence of her rights and your rights in the Union.
Untamed by adversity — uninfluenced by present or approaching dangers — with a cherished remembrance of her past glories, she bids defiance to all enemies of the Union, North or South; self-poised, in her own self-reliance she will never, like a spoilt child, flee, by secession, from the Union.
But she will assert all of her constitutional rights in the Union and under the Constitution, so long as there is a Union or common Constitution in existence.

"Such being the purpose — as steady as it is resolute, and inflexible as it is brave — of Virginia, I have been pained and chafed, when I hear, in this community, doubts and misgivings thrown out as to the fidelity of Virginia to the South.
Men of Alabama, these are libels upon Virginia, and the position sought to be assigned her by your gifted, eloquent and brave son, W. L. Yancey, was as unjust as it was ungenerous, and unfaithful as it was unmanly. This much I feel called upon to say here, and before this audience.
I disclaim all personalities; but I will here shield my beloved mother from those imputations, and feel proud, as one of her humblest sons, of the opportunity.

"Virginia untrue to the South!
Virginia, a border State, in a Northern Confederacy, playing second to a Black Republican, fanatical set of social and governmental disorganizers!
Sirs, in the pride of my nativity I spurn the very intimation.
Yea, more.
I will here undertake to speak for Virginia, and make known her position.
I suppose that Mr. Lincoln is elected.
Will Virginia secede on that account, without some 'palpable infraction of the Constitution? ' I say for her — no, no, never, never.
Virginia respects her compacts, and she intends to stand by them.
She feels too proud of her past history — too potent in her own sovereignty — to quail and tremble and give way at the knees, before even a Black Republican President.
But she is not a submissionist State.
She will assert and maintain her rights — as she will defend yours.
She will face the enemy and cry aloud and spare not, though every cotton State may desert her and seek refuge by secession.
She will choose her ground — fight, nobly fight her own battles, to the death if need be.

"I am asked, what will be her policy, should South Carolina secede — in the event of Mr. Lincoln's election — and the Federal Government should attempt to coerce her by force, and with that intent seek to march an abolition army across the soil of Virginia?
I answer from my heart--as long as there is a true Virginian left above the sod — or one of her noble and lovely daughters left to shed a tear her borders to invade your rights, or stain your soil with the blood of your people--that is my answer here to-day, Alabamians, to you. And is this the State that your son — brilliant as he is eloquent, and strong-willed as he is erratic — has sought to misrepresent and misplace, in the great and terrific struggle that may be so close at hand?
Virginia! mother of States and statesmen --would that my voice could now ring through your every valley, as it does through this hall, that this people might hear your response!
Virginia, a truant to the South!
When the last sad conflict comes — as soon it may — Virginia will lead where the bravest may be proud to follow, and where many of those who, in the 'sunny South,' seek to deride and defame her, will hesitate to follow her.'With her martial cloak around her,' she will sound forth, from every valley, the bugle-blast of defiance, and shed her best blood to screen those who now seem to doubt her fidelity."

I believe now, as then, that the period in our history as a nation has arrived when, face to face the people of the North and South should fully understand each other on the slavery question; and that every practical issue which now exists, or may hereafter arise, must be finally and satisfactorily settled; and this not by patch work nor promises, but by well matured and deliberately sanctioned amendments to the Federal Constitution. This, in my opinion, is absolutely necessary, or civil war is the inevitable alternative.

But by whom, and how, are the proposed and necessary amendments to the Constitution to be insisted on and sustained?
Surely, not by States out of the Union? They must necessarily be proposed, sustained and perfected by States in the Union.
Hence, it is my opinion that there is (under the existing relations between the States which have already seceded, and those which may secede between this and the 4th of March, and the Federal Government,) the most imperious necessity, which demands that Virginia should remain in the Union, where she can, and will, under the flag of the Union, command the peace between the extreme Northern and Southern States.

If out of the Union, the vantage ground is lost: in the Union, Virginia would hold the balance, and no Federal arm could ever be raised against her. She now occupies the middle ground.
She has, authoritatively, announced her position on the question of coercion.
She has, with calm dignity, forbidden the coercive policy towards any seceding State.
Her honor and her flag stand firmly interposed between the Federal Government and the seceding States.
Then, peace or war must flow from the Federal Government.
If coercion is attempted, Virginia has pledged her honor to arrest the blow. How, then, can the coercive policy be adopted and exercised while Virginia is in the Union?

In America no government can exist by force.
The Federal Government is but the creature of the people; and if the incoming Administration dare attempt the coercive policy, over Virginia in the Union, the President and his Cabinet will be much more easily gibbeted than they can subjugate the smallest State.

But if Virginia were out of the Union, by formal secession, she could not, and ought not, to exert the same influence.
In a word, when coercion is attempted, if Virginia interposes the flag of the Union on the same battle-field on which her own flag is unfurled, no American hand will be raised against it.

You will thus perceive that I am no advocate for secession on the one hand, or submission on the other.
Peaceable secession is a mere political vagary.
Physical coercion is worse than a vagary.
The arm uplifted to strike down the flag of one of the original thirteen States in the Union, and raised in defence of the constitutional rights of the people, would fall, palsied, in the face of the civilized world.

If war — civil war — is inevitable, let it come on us in the Union, and we can but re-conquer our liberties or die in the noble defence of our rights, under that flag which has hitherto been the proud escutcheon of a free and enlightened people.
For that flag, and under its ample folds, I am prepared to do all in my power, in war or peace, in support of constitutional liberty and constitutional freedom, as opposed to provisional governments, internecine strife, and civil war.
div4.closer:
Your fellow-citizen, John H. Gilmer.
Richmond, January 19, 1861. ja 21--1t*

div3.head: A Card.
div3.p:
--The numerous friends of our popular townsman, David J. Saunders, Sr., Esq., who propose him as a candidate for the State Convention, soon to assemble in this city, will not adopt the easy and too common plan by spreading in print the two or three hundred names which could be procured in a few hours as a call for his services; but will give a few reasons why we present him and intend to unite on and vote for him: He has served the city ably in the Council for more than ten consecutive years; his whole course has been approved by all as our delegate in the Legislature; his prompt, indefatigable exertions in behalf and support of this city and State, are acknowledged and appreciated by his constituents.
With such men we will have little talk — a heap of work — decisive and ready action.
If he proclaims himself a candidate, he will receive the support and votes of
ja 21--1t* Legion.

div3.head: To the people of Hanover, a Card.
div3.p:
--I must reply at once to the kind and flattering call on me in to-day's Enquirer. I should not have announced myself a candidate for the Convention.
The solemn concerns involved, the right of the people to select their representative unembarrassed by personal motives, in my opinion, forbid my doing so. I can, therefore, only say, that I accept gratefully and willingly this position assigned me by that call; but subject to the condition that my doing so must not constrain or embarrass the supporters of Southern rights in any course they may think proper to pursue.
C. W. Dabney.
Hanover, 18th January, 1861. ja 21 --d&aw2ts

div3.head: To the Voters of the city of Richmond.
div3.p:
--Believing Col. Samuel T. Bayly to be eminently qualified to represent this city in part, in the Convention, we take this method to call upon him to announce himself a candidate.
Col. B. is well known to this community as a gentleman of fine ability, and has always belonged to the State-Rights school of politicians.
He will receive the cordial support of [ja 21--1t*] Monroe Ward.

div3.head: To Dr. Z. S. McGruder.
div3.p: --We, a portion of the voters of Henrico county, being desirous of obtaining the services of the best and ablest men of our county, and knowing you to be faithful and true to our interests, (having ably represented us in the Legislature.) request that you will allow us the use of your name as a candidate for the State Convention, believing it will be the pleasure of a large majority to elect you. [ja 21--1t*] many Voters.

div3.head: Card.
div3.p: --Respect for those friends who, too highly estimating my fitness for a membership of the approaching State Convention, have placed my name as a candidate before the citizens of Richmond, requires me to say that I do not possess the statesmanship and experience which I think should qualify every member of that most important body: and, therefore, with thanks for their partiality, I respectfully decline being a candidate.
ja 21--2t Charles Dimmock.

placeName.reg: Virginia, United States, North and Central America

div3.p: --citizens' Ticket.
Judge John Robertson,
J. Randolph Tucker,
Patrick Henry Aylett.

The above ticket will be voted for by all citizens who desire to maintain Virginia's rights, in the Union or out of it, at all hazards.
ja 21--ts

div3.head: To James M. Estes, Wm. M. Caldwell, and others.
div3.p: --Gentlemen: In reply to your call, which appears in the Dispatch of this morning, I can only say that, whilst the magnitude of the interests involved in the contest now raging in the country, and the greatness of the responsibility which will weigh upon the Convention, takes from me all anxiety to be a member of that body, they, at the same time, forbid me to decline any position to which the people of Richmond may call me. If, therefore, they shall be pleased to elect me to the Convention, I will discharge the trust with all the ability I possess, and certainly with fidelity to the great interests involved.

My opinions have already been expressed in a public meeting of the citizens of Richmond, and I have heard nothing since to change them.
My opinion is: Safety and security in the Union, or out of it. Peachy R. Grattan.
January 18th, 1861. ja 19--ts

div3.head: To Messrs. Jas. M. Estes. J. B. Ferguson, Jr., and others.
div3.p: --Gentlemen: In reply to the call which you have been kind enough to make upon me, through the columns of the Dispatch, inviting me to declare myself a candidate for the Convention, I can only say, that if the citizens of Richmond desire my services in that body, I do not feel at liberty to refuse them, although the responsibility of the position will be so grave that my personal preference is to avoid it. Having recently had occasion to express my opinions before a meeting of the citizens, it is only necessary for me to say that they are unchanged, and that I am now, as I was then, in favor of prompt and energetic action, to secure the honor and safety of the State in this Confederacy, if practicable; if not, in some other.

I have the honor to remain, gentlemen, your obedient servant.
Geo. W. Randolph.

div3.head: Messrs. Editors:
div3.p:
Among the many names mentioned by the people of this city as one of the delegates to represent us in the State Convention, is Mr. Wm. G. Dunbar, a young lawyer of this city, a gentleman of fine attainments, refined manners, sound sense, and correct, liberal and conservative views on all subjects.
A life-long Democrat, though a supporter of Douglas in the late canvass, he could, perhaps, command as large a support as any one that could be named.
But his politics should not be an objection.
He would do justice to the position.
He is a popular young man, and will be supported by the [ja 19--3t*] people of Richmond.

div4.p: -- Believing that, in the present crisis of our country's affairs, the best and most reliable men should be called to the councils of the State, and knowing that you possess the qualifications requisite to represent the true interests of Virginia in the State Convention about to be held, we earnestly request you to allow your name to be presented to the voters of the city as one of their delegates to said Convention.

opener.salute:
To Messrs. George W. Hobson, Samuel J. Harrison, R. H. Meade, P. T. Moore, and others.
Gentlemen:

div4.p:
My attention has been called to your letter in the Dispatch of this morning, requesting that I would allow my name to be presented to the voters of Richmond as a candidate for the State Convention, to be held on the 13th of February next.
Unaffectedly distrustful of my qualification for so high and responsible a position, it would be more agreeable to me, personally, that the trust should be confided to some one more able and experienced than myself; but in the present crisis of our affairs, demanding, in my judgment, the promptest and most decided measures for the protection and preservation of the rights of Virginia, (in the Union, if possible; if not, then out of it,) I do not feel at liberty to withhold from my native State any service which so large and respectable a portion of my fellow-citizens may think it in my power to render.
You are at liberty, therefore, to use my name as you desire, with the assurance that, should it be the pleasure of my fellow-citizens of Richmond to confer upon me so distinguished a trust, I shall endeavor to discharge it with firmness and fidelity.
While, gentlemen, I have confided my name to you, to be used as you may deem best for the promotion of those high interests so dear to us all, you must permit me to express the earnest hope that you will at once withdraw it when ever the success of those interests and the cordial union of our friends shall demand it. Thanking you, gentlemen, for the kind and too partial sentiments expressed in your letter.
div4.closer: I am, very truly, Your friend and fellow-citizen. ja 17--ts John O. Steger.

div3.p: --I earnestly entreat the citizens of Hanover to attend a meeting to be held at our next County Court, for the purpose of uniting on a man to represent us in the State Convention, to be held in Richmond on the 13th of February. His extremely requisite to use our most active and united efforts to secure the services of one whose qualifications are best adapted to meet the present perilous condition of the country.

figure.figDesc: Page image of Daily Dispatch, Volume 19, Number 18, page 3.

div3.head:
From Washington.
[Special correspondence of the Dispatch.]
div3.p:
Poor creation how much good it does 'em, after being cooped up a day or-two, to come set and show themselves in their newest rigging and have some out-door gabble.
Pennsylvania Avenue was full of them yesterday afternoon.
They were especially numerous in the story of a chap who has just opened a washed-jewelry swindle a few doors below Kirkwood's. He sells anything he's got for a dollar — splendid mosaic ear-rings, a set of the heaviest pure silver spoons, and the like of that.
To-day, all is dark and dreary again.
The poor creatures are forced back to their needles and their novels.

Mr. Ro. E. Scott's long-delayed letter will appear in the Alexandria Gazette of Monday next.
If every Virginian were as true to the honor of his State as the gentleman just named, and if all of us will back Gov. Letcher in his plucky response to the coercive resolutions of the Black Republican Legislature of New York.
I warrant the Old Dominion with emerge gloriously from the cloud of her present obscure and doubtful position.

Owing to the horrid weather, and the certainty that Congress can do nothing new, I have not been to the Capitol for some days, and can I tell how Mr. Pryor's peace proposition are getting along.
From the tone of yesterday's Tribune, I should say there was no hope of any compromise whatever.
As week after week rolls by, it becomes more and more evident that a new order of things is being arranged by the hand of Providence, despite the best efforts alike of good and bad men to prevent it by keeping matters as they are. A well- known gentleman said yesterday that our fathers made this Government for sensible people, and the only reason it did not answer now is because we have all turned fools.--"Not to put too fine a point upon it," I accept this solution of the existing political problem as the neatest, if not the most scientific and exact yet made.
Of one thing we may be well assured — a thorough going change there must be.

As the great States of the North have virtually declared war against us, would it not be a sort of compensation, (unlooked for, but not the less welcome,) if the North western States which Virginia gave to the Republic should step forth and say, "Hands off. There shall be no fighting.
If we must part, we part in peace.
Nothing is to be gained, much to be lost by fighting." Illinois, in her Democratic. Convention, has said so. Let Ohio and Indians profit by the example.

A Virginia matron, 80 years old, has written to her son-in-law in this city to buy her a pistol.
She closes by saying " I am for peace; but if the war must come, I think I can kill two or three of the Abolitionists if they invade Virginia" One of the Texas delegates tells me that every woman and child there will fight; for when in his speeches, he sought to impress upon the ladies the fact that secession might prove no holiday affair, but bring he knew not what dangers to every fireside, they invariably cheered him on by applauding and waving their handkerchiefs — thus manifesting their willingness to confront any danger which might grow out of a separation from the wretches who had poisoned their wells, burnt their houses, and incited their slaves to insurrection.
I tell you, these people you call women are the bravest of the brave.
All history proves it.

An inspection of the Zouaves at the Theatre last night inclines me to believe that they are a detachments of the regular corps of the French Theatre in New York.
They don't handle their muskets like fellows who have been in the Crimea — that is, if I am any judge.
Uncle Sam's "soldiers," just from Leaven worth, are engaging freely in the delights of Washington life.
They don't "skewer" you much to look at them.
Zed.

div3.head:
Correspondence of the Richmond Dispatch.
letter from Charleston--Black Republican Misrepresentations, &c.
div3.p:
You have seen, no doubt, going the rounds of the newspapers at the North, many slanderous reports concerning our people, in this their struggle against Black Republican rule.
We expect nothing else from them; but some of your readers may, perchance, suppose that such things may exist.
It is for their benefit, the sons and daughters of my dear old mother, Virginia that I write.

One Lander is, that our citizens have to submit to forced Loans, to support the army.
This I first saw in the N. Y. Tribune, and again in that other Republican sheet, the Boston Daily Advertiser.
I give it the flat and palpable lie. No such thing has occurred in this State.
There is no need of any such expedient.

Another untruth: A company of volunteers on their way to this city, called at a widow lady's house and demanded dinner and contributions and left without paying.
This is utterly unfounded.

Yet another: That the Irish and German volunteers were disaffected.
No greater slander was ever heaped upon any people.
I happen to know, quite intimately, the five captains commanding the five German companies, and many of their officers and men, and I assure you they were the first to offer their services to the State; and they are not only in the foremost ranks of our volunteers, but nothing but the most glowing patriotism animates them.
This I know.

The Irish Volunteers are commanded by Capt. E. Magrath, (the survivor of that terrible duel which occurred here in 1856,) and I have never seen greater enthusiasm displayed among any body of men. They were the first to discover the "Star of the West." So you may put this slander upon our adopted soldiers down as a Black Republican lie.
And yet another: It has been said by our enemies that our city is governed by mob law.

A very intelligent gentleman from Pittsylvania county is now in this city, and he said this morning, to his surprise, he had never seen so orderly and quiet a city in all his travels. --I assure you that I have not seen three drunken men in this city in as many months, and there is the greatest decorum observed in the camp and in the city.
No people are more celebrated for the strictest order and decorum than are the Charlestonians, and persons from abroad cannot misbehave here.
Then, set this down as the grossest slander.

The news from Washington to-day is not at all satisfactory.
I will give you on to-morrow some interesting facts in connection with the noted "Star of the West," Fort Sumpter, and our army, and will keep you advised from day to-day as to things transpiring in our midst, which you may rely on.
Virginias.

div3.head:
Correspondence of the Richmond Dispatch.
public sentiment West of the Mountains.
div3.p:
Persons here are glad to see that the Dispatch denies a want of loyalty to the State west of the Blue Ridge.
Public sentiment in this county has changed much in the last few weeks.
We have some violent secessionists, who land the brave and manly course of South Carolina.
Still, the majority say we must now secede, though we abhor the idea of following South Carolina.
Some of the leaders who followed Governor Letcher's theory now yield a mournful acquiescence, adding that it galls them to be drawn into civil war by a ranting little State.
But the secessionists are fast making converts.
In case of civil war I have no doubt that Greenbrier will furnish some as brave and loyal troops as ever marched to repel an invader.
There are several volunteer companies in the county.

Of the three newspapers in Lewisburg, one urges secession, a second opposes coercion, and the third deprecates civil war; or, rather, the two last are Whig, waiting for the interposition of Providence to avert the impending calamity.

The weather for some days has been clear, cold and calm.
The snow is disappearing. --Neither the Greenbrier river nor any of its considerable tributaries have been frozen over his winter.
Charley.

div3.head:
Correspondence of the Richmond Dispatch.
the secession feeling on the increase.
div3.p:
Although this is a most conservative and temperate neighborhood, the secession feeling is greatly on the increase.
Our last hope of maintaining our rights in the Union was centred in Senators Crittenden and Douglas, and the result of their efforts has greatly strengthened the secession party here, and weaned many Union-loving sons from their unnatural mother.
A magnificent flag spans the street at the Court-House; cockades are numerous, and the students of the College have organized a military company, under a Captain who received his military training at a Connecticut Military Institute; and if their services are needed, we will guarantee the Yankee agitators a warm reception at their hands.
Rutherford.

div3.head: North Carolina Bonds.
div3.p: --The Bank of the Republic, at New York, under instructions from the Governor of North Carolina, announces that it will pay the interest on all the bonds of the State, without regard to the late fraud in the Interior Department.

div3.head: Fire and loss of life.
div3.p:
--A house, owned by Mrs. Elizabeth McNally, in Charleston, S. C., was consumed by fire on the morning of the 18th inst.
Mrs. McNally, in attempting to make her way down stairs, was suffocated and burnt to death.

div3.head: Books.
div3.p:
--During the last year the value of the book exports of France amounted to more than half a million sterling.
Among the importing countries, England is second on the list, and Belgium first.
The Secretary of the Navy has accepted the resignations of Lieut. Chapman and Master Mills, (both Alabamans,) of the Brooklyn.
Mr. Z. Lewis, Sr one of the oldest citizens of Albemarle county, Va., died a few days since.

div3.head:
Important from Georgia.
secession of the Empire State of
the South.
enthusiasm of the people.
div3.p:
--The State Convention, at 10 minutes past 2 o'clock, passed the ordinance of immediate secession by a vote of 208 to 89.
It will be made nearly unanimous.
The Convention adopted the following ordinance to dissolve the union between the State of Georgia and the other States united with her under a compact entitled the Constitution of the United States:

q.p: "We, the people of the State of Georgia, do declare, ordain, and it is hereby declared and ordained, that the ordinance adopted by the people of Georgia, in convention, in the year 1788, whereby the Constitution of the United States was assented to, ratified and adopted, and also all acts and parts of acts of the General Assembly ratifying and adopting the amendments to the said Constitution, are hereby repealed, rescinded and abrogated; and we do further declare and ordain that the union now subsisting between the State of Georgia and the other States, under the name of the United States of America, is hereby dissolved; and that the State of Georgia is in the full possession and exercise of all those rights of sovereignty which belong and appertain to a free and independent State.

div3.p:
Augusta, Jan. 19.--Our city is illuminated with fire-works, and cannon are firing in honor of the secession of the State.
Bells are ringing amid great enthusiasm and rejoicing.

div3.head: From Washington.
div3.p:
--The minority report of the Committee of Thirty-Three, which is signed by Taylor of Louisiana, Phelps of Missouri, Rust of Arkansas, Whitley of Delaware, and Winslow of North Carolina, embraces, in substance, the following: that the changes which have taken place in the situation and sentiments of the people of the different States since the formation of the Constitution have been such that through the misconstruction of some of its provisions, and the willful perversion of others, and the introduction of new principles in forming parties which are in direct antagonism with the usages and opinions of the whole American people when the Constitution went into effect, that instrument has ceased to accomplish some of the most important ends aimed at by its adoption.
The difference between the Northern and Southern sections of the Confederacy from this cause has at last risen to such a height that they have resulted in the formation of a sectional party in the North, of the slavery question alone, which will practically exclude the Southern people from any voice in the management of national affairs, in which they have a common interest with their Northern brethren, and that as this fact, notwithstanding the Republican forms of the Constitution are preserved, in truth destroys the spirit of Republicanism in the Government, it is therefore impossible that the two sections should any longer go on together as one people, unless the existing state of things is remedied.

The report proceeds to say that the present difficulties can only be remedied by amendments to the Constitution, and suggests the amendments proposed in the Crittenden resolutions.
If adopted, they would restore tranquility to the country, and place the Union on such a foundation that it could never again be shaken.
These amendments would not in reality change the Constitution, they would only have the effect of restoring it, by the added propositions, to what it was in point of fact on the day of its adoption, through the operation of the circumstances which then surrounded it, and which erected barriers against the present sectional contest then, as the constitutional propositions would now.--If a constitutional majority cannot be united in support of Crittenden's resolutions, or the substance of them, then a dissolution of the Union is inevitable.

The report recommends that steps be taken for calling a Convention of the States, with a view of peaceable separation by providing for a partition of the common property of the United States, settling the terms on which social and commercial intercourse between the separated States shall be conducted, and making a permanent arrangement with respect to the navigation of the Mississippi river.
The report gives what the signers consider a full account of the rise and progress of the slavery agitation, which produced the existing difficulties.

Letters from a distinguished source in Georgia, say that though that State considers it her duty to secede, she is willing to re-unite with the other States on a satisfactory guarantee of her political and social safety.
She takes the secession step at this time in obedience to what she considers her vita interest.

Two nights ago, Fort Pickens, Fla., was in immediate danger of assault; but since, a dispatch, signed by numerous secessionists in Congress, has been sent thither, their friends urging them by all means to avoid a collision with the Federal forces.
There seems to be no danger, therefore, of an immediate conflict in that quarter.

Col. Hayne, of S. C., will remain in Washington ten days or two weeks longer.
His visit has been productive of great good in the interest of peace.
It is not apprehended that any attack will at present be made on Fort Sumter.

The Alabama members of Congress await instructions from their State.
Those from Georgia will remain until they receive an official copy of the Ordinance of Secession.

Active measures are in progress to have the course of Virginia, in sending Commissioners to Washington on the 4th of February, responded to by similar movements in all the States.
Dispatches have been sent to Harrisburg, Pa.; Albany, N. Y.; Columbus, Ohio, and other State Capitals where Legislatures are in session, urging the prompt appointment of good and able men to confer with the Virginia Commissioners.

Washington is now more free from excitement than at any time since the commencement of the session of Congress.
Apprehensions of difficulties attending the inauguration of Lincoln exist, but to a limited extend.--However, to guard against any possible disturbance, ample measures have been taken to preserve the peace.
With the probable action of Louisiana this week, the secession movement will be retarded as to other States.
A company of sappers and miners, from West Point, acting as infantry, arrived here to-day, and are quartered at the Columbian armory.

div3.head: The proposed attack on Ft. Pickens--prompt action in Florida.
div3.p:
--The Mayor replied to Gov. Chase that 2,000 men could be raised in 48 hours, if Florida would equip them.
The Governor of Florida answered "send them immediately."
There is considerable excitement here.--Meetings will be held to-morrow.
New Orleans, Jan. 19.--The pilots at Pensacola have been notified not to bring in U. S. vessels, on penalty of death.
A ship is ashore fifteen miles east of Fort Pickens, supposed to be the supply storeship with officers of the navy-yard aboard.
Lieut. Slimmer, commanding Fort Pickens, expected to surrender the Florida forts, save twenty-five heavy guns.

div3.head: Alabama Legislature.
div3.p: --The House to-day passed a bill to provide against the invasion of the State by sea; declares that pilots bringing vessels into Mobile are liable to a fine and imprisonment in the penitentiary, and also authorizing the commander of Fort Morgan to destroy the beacon and landmarks in his discretion, and contract for the construction of a telegraph line to Point Clear, in order to more speedily communicate with Fort Morgan.

It is understood that J. J. Hooper, Esq., of the Montgomery Mail, will be a candidate for clerk of the Southern Congress.
He will be strongly supported by the secessionists.
The Convention has been in secret session all day.

div3.head: The Missouri Legislature.
div3.p: --The House concurred in the slight amendments made by the Senate yesterday to the Convention bill, and the bill was finally passed.
The amendment reads as follows:

q.p: "No act, ordinance or resolution shall be valid to change or dissolve the political relations of this State to the government of the United States or any other State, until a majority of the qualified voters of the State shall ratify the same."

div3.p: Mr. Russell, the Commissioner from Mississippi, made a strong secession speech before a joint convention of both Houses of the Legislature last night.

div3.head: The New Jersey Legislature.
div3.p:
--The majority of the Joint Committee on National Affairs, reported a series of resolutions to the Senate, fully endorsing the Crittenden resolutions, and instructing the Senators of the State in Congress, and requesting the Representatives to support them.
They will be discussed next week and passed by both Houses, no doubt.
The committee also call upon Congress to order a National Convention in case Crittenden's or similar measures are not speedily adopted.

div3.head: Mississippi Legislature.
div3.p: --The Committee on the Confederacy in the Mississippi Legislature, have reported resolutions to provide for a Southern Confederacy and establish a Provisional Government for the seceding States.--The proposed separate Convention meets at Montgomery on the 4th of February.

div3.head: The Louisiana Convention.
div3.p: --The result of a recent election for delegates to a State Convention was two to one in favor of secession.

div3.head: Arrival of the Teutonia
div3.p: --The steamship Teutonia arrived this evening.

div3.head:
Arrival of the Steamer Asia.
further European advices.
div3.p: --The steamer Asia, from Liverpool on the 5th inst., arrived below last night, but was detained on account of ice in the bay until this morning.
Four screw steamers from New York were over due at Liverpool when the Asia sailed.
The steamers Marathon and City of Washington have been substituted for the steamers Kedar and Vigo.
The Cork "Examiner" starts a rumor that the Prince of Wales is to be Lord Lieutenant of Ireland, but it was not credited.
It was reported that the British Government had sent a strong note to France against an extension of the French occupation of Syria.
The ship Ohio, from New Orleans, bound to Liverpool, was spoken on the 17th ult., in a damaged condition, having had to throw part of her cargo overboard.
It was reported that the correspondence between France and England, relative to the French fleet before Gaeta, was of an unsatisfactory character.

The state of affairs at Gaeta were unchanged.
It was reported that negotiations were pending for the extension of an armistice.
Count Franpani is said to be heading a reactionary movement in Abruzzi.
The Prince Regent of Prussia has commenced his reign as William V. He reiterated his principles and his policy the same as when he assumed the Regency.
Two Sardinian vessels with war materials had been seized by the Russians at Galatz.

The Bombay Mail of December 12th had reached Marseilles.
The income tax troubles continued and the import trade was suspended.

div4.head: Commercial intelligence.
div4.p:
--Cotton — Sales to-day of 8,000 bales. The market closes steady.
Stock in port, 118,000 bales.

Manchester advices unfavorable.
There is but little inquiry, and prices are weak.
Breadstuffs — The market is steady.--Wheat is quiet at full prices — red 11s. 3d@13s. 3d.; white 12s. 6d.@14s. Corn is dull at a decline of 6s.--mixed and yellow 38s. 6d.; white 40s. and 41s.
Richardson, Spence & Co. quote Flour 6d. higher.
Messrs. Wakefield & Nash report Flour steady at extreme prices, say 29s. @32s. 6d.
London Markets.--The money market was generally unchanged, although there was continued activity.
Consols closed at 92 Ȃ@92 ½ for account.
Bullion in the Bank of England had decreased £145,000 sterling.

The Paris Bourse closed dull.
Rentes 67f. 55

div3.head: South Carolina.
div3.p:
--Lieut. Talbot, Col. Anderson's messenger from Washington, arrived here last night, with gloomy tidings, it is said.
The Legislature was in secret session nearly the entire night on the subject.
This morning a white flag came from Fort Sumter, the object of which, it is stated, is to demand a suspension of work on the fortifications in the harbor.

Lieut. Davis, with four men, is now in the city.
The soldiers are witnesses in a murder case, and Lieut. Davis is being entertained by his friends.
He drinks to a peaceable settlement of the difficulties.
Fort Sumter is allowed to procure fresh provisions from our market daily.

div3.head: Loss of the brig Quickstep.
div3.p:
--The British brig Quickstep, from Trinidad for London, was abandoned at sea. The captain and four of the crew were brought here by the ship.
Flora Southard.
The rest of the crew, four in number, were washed overboard and drowned.

div3.head: Sale of a Railroad.
div3.p: --The Milwaukee and Mississippi Railroad was sold to-day by the Marshal, on the order of the U. S. District Court, and was purchased by the trustees of the creditors and assenting stockholders.

div3.head: The bids for the $5,000,000 loan.
div3.p: --Mr. Dix, Secretary of the Treasury, opened at noon about one hundred bids for the five million loan ranging from 9 to 12 per centum.

div3.head: Contemplated attack on Fort Pickens.
div3.p: --The commander of the Florida forces has telegraphed the Mayor of this city for 2,000 men to aid in taking Fort Pickens.

div3.head: Death of Lola Montez.
div3.p: --Lola Montez died on Thursday.

div4.p:
--Cotton closed Ȃ ct. higher.
Sales of 4,000 bales--uplands middlings 12 ½.
Flour closed firm — sales 13,500 barrels. State $5.20@$5.25; Ohio $5.70@5.80; Southern & 5.80@6.10.--Wheat closed firm — sales of 42,000 bushels; white Western $1.55; red $1.35. Corn steady — sales of 54,000 bushels; mixed 70@71 cts. Pork closed firm — mess $17.50@17.75; prime dull at $13.12 ½@13.25 Lard steady at 10 ½@10 cts. Whiskey steady at 18 ½.
Sugar closed firm.
Orleans 5 3/6@6 ½ cts.; Muscovado 5 ¼@6 cts. Coffee steady — sales 3,900 bags at 11@13 cts. Molasses firm at 37@39.
Spirits Turpentine steady at 35 @37 cts. Rosin firm at $1.25 per bbl. Rice steady 4@4 ½ cts.
Sales of $3,000 Va. 6's at $76 ½, and $5,000 North Carolina State 6's at $78 ¼.

--Flour closed active at 12 ½ cents advance, with large sales; Howard street and Ohio $5.50. Wheat firm; Red $1.30@$1.35; white $1.45@1.65.
Corn steady; New white and yellow 63@67 cents. Provisions firm.
Mess Pork $18; prime rump $13. Lard 10 Ȃ cents.
Coffee steady at 12@13 cents.

div3.head: Old Dominion Insurance Company.

table.head: Office, no. 42 Main St., under St. Charles Hotel.

div3.p: Fire and Marine Risks taken on favor--
reasonable terms.

In addition to the ordinary mode of Insurance, this Company issues Perpetual Policies, on Buildings, on the payment of eight Annual Premiums.
Property is thenceforth permanently insured.
By this plan a saving is effected, and the risk and inconvenience of renewals are avoided.
The policy can be canceled at any time by the holder, the premium being returned, less ten percent.
Applications for Insurance will receive prompt attention.

Chas. E. Wortham, Sec'ry.
de 31--ts

The Peculiarities of the Female Constitution and the various trials to which the sex is subjected, demand an occasional recourse to stimulants.
It is important, however, that these shall be of a harmless nature, and at the same time accomplish the desired end. Hostetter's celebrated Stomach Bitters is the very article.
Its effects in all cases of debility are almost magical.
It restores the tone of the digestive organs, infuses fresh vitality in the whole system and gives that cheerfulness to the temperament which is the most valuable of feminine attractions.
The proprietors feel flattered from the fact that many of the most prominent medical gentlemen in the Union have bestowed encomiums upon the Bitters, the virtues of which they have frequently tested and acknowledged.
There are numerous counterfeits offered for sale, all of which are destitute of merit, and positively injurious to the system.
Sold by Druggists and dealers generally everywhere.
de 10--dtF1

div3.head: An act of gratitude.
div3.p:
--20,000 Copies of A Medical Book for Gratuitous Circulation, by a Sufferer, who has been effectually cured of Nervous Debility, Loss of Memory, and Dimness of Sight, resulting from early errors, by following the instructions given in a medical work.
Considers it his duty in gratitude to the author, and for the benefit of Consumptive and Nervous sufferers, to publish the means used.
He will, therefore, send free to any address, on receipt of two stamps, a copy of the work, containing every information required.
Address, "Box 579," P. O., Albany, N. Y. no 12--d&cw3m

Spotswood Hotel Hair-Dressing Saloon. Geo. J. Hisserich, the celebrated Hair Cutter and Artist of his profession, respectfully informs the citizens of Richmond that he has taken charge of the new and elegantly fitted up Hairdressing Saloon under the Spotswood Hotel, where he will at all times be ready to give Hot and Cold and Shower Baths, and attend to everything in the line of his profession,
ja 1--1m

div3.head: For Rent
div3.p:
--My store-House and lot, at Centreville, Louisa county.
It has every convenience that can be asked for — good dwelling and store-house, all necessary out-houses, excellent garden, a splendid well of water, plenty of fire-wood convenient, and land to cultivate.
It is a most healthy situation, and in a good neighborhood.
It is a most excellent stand for a dry goods and grocery store, or a mechanic of any kind.
Any one wishing to rent, will apply to the subscriber.
Tallison B. Mills.
My address is "Harris' Post-Office, Louisa county, Va." ja 19 --d2t&cw1t*

div3.head: For Rent
div3.p: --The excellent Dwelling-House recently occupied by Dr. J. V. Hobson, on 5th street, in the rear of J. C. Hobson, Esq., Main street. The house is supplied throughout with gas, water, bath fixtures, &c. It has a stable and carriage-house in the rear, and office in basement of dwelling.
Also, for Hire — Several Negro Cooks, House Servants, Farm Hands, Factory Boys, &c. Apply to Redwood & Keach,
ja 19--3t Basement Metropolitan Hall.

div3.head: Water-power for Rent.
div3.p: --The premises on 12th street, near the Gallego Mills, formerly used as a Barrel Manufactory, is for rent.

The improvements consist of a large Frame Building 60 by 32 feet, with three good floors and a basement; and two good fire-proof one-story Brick Buildings in the yard, which are well adapted for kiln drying all kinds of timber.
There is under the main building an over-shot Water Wheel of about twenty horse power, by which the machinery through the house is driven.

Persons desirous of renting the above property are referred to Mr. Joseph Hall for further particulars and a more minute description of the property.
Warwick & Barksdale.
ja 18--cod3w

div3.head: Agricultural Fair Grounds for Rent.
div3.p:

The tenant will be allowed the use of an excellent Brick House and the Saloons, with the privilege of cultivating, as a garden, ten acres of land, and using the Horse Track and Stables for a Trotting Park, subject to such regulations as the Executive Committee may prescribe, which will be made known before renting.
The rent must be paid quarterly, and bond, with good security, given for it. Apply to
de 25--ts James Lyons, Pres't.

div3.head: Notice to shippers and others.
div3.p:
--The Yorktown has been withdrawn from the line for the present.
The Jamestown, Capt. Skinner, and the Roanoke, Capt. Couch, will continue their trips between this city and New York, touching at Norfolk each day.
Days of departure from New York, every Tuesday and Saturday, at 3 P. M. Days of departure from Richmond, every Tuesday and Friday, at 4 P. M. Ludlam & Watson.
de 6--ts

div3.head: Change of hour for starting for Portsmouth and Norfolk.
div3.p: --The Steamer Glen Cove will, on and after Friday Morning next, 30th inst., leave her wharf at Rocketts, regularly every Friday, Monday and Wednesday Mornings, at 6 ½ o'clock precisely, for the above places, and return each alternate day, (except Sunday,) leaving Norfolk at the same hour, 6 ½ o'clock, and touch at all of the regular landings on the river, going and returning.
no 27--ts R. O. Haskins.

div3.head: Cox's line.
div3.p: --Freight Boats to Lynchburg three times A week--Tuesdays; Thursdays and Saturdays.
Boat Tempest, Capt. Thos. Emett.
Boat Merchant, Capt Geo. C. Layne,
Boat Bristol, Capt. Chas. J. Johnson,
Boat J. J. Irby, Capt. Wm. F. Cleveland.
Boat Fame, Capt. Wm. H. Parsons.
Boat Olivia, Capt. J. J. Peters.

These Boats are all of the first class, commanded by careful and experienced Captains, and leave promptly as advertised.
The subscriber, thankful for past favors, begs a continuance of the same.
Wm. P. Cox. Agent.
At the Shed, Dock st., in rear of old Gas Works.

div3.head: Richmond-made Pianos for sale below Northern prices.
div3.p: --The subscriber has on hand three new, very superior 7 octave Pianos, which he warrants to be equal, if not superior, to any instrument of the same quality from Northern manufactories.

He also offers his services to the public as Tuner and Repairer of Pianos, at reasonable rates.
Conrad Freimann,
North side Broad st., between 2d and 3d.
References.--H. P. Lefebvre, Esq., Prof. E. W. Thilow, Prof. W. F. Grabau, &c. no 14--6m

div3.head: A large Number of Lots in the city of Richmond and Lands in Henrico County for sale, barter or Exchange.
div3.p:
--The subscriber will sell, upon the usual terms — say, one-fourth in cash, 6, 12, 18 and 24 months for the residue — a large number of Lots in the city, for the most part in rapidly-improving localities; also, several Tracts of land in Henrico county, of fair quality as to soil, and heavily timbered.
Or will barter or exchange them for any approved stocks, at current prices.
For plats and information as to this property, apply to James E. Goddin,
ja 15--2w No. 8 Belvin's Block.

div3.head: Henrico Squadron.
div3.p: --The organization of a Squadron of Cavalry being authorized by Henrico County Court, citizens proposing to attach themselves thereto will please meet at the County Court-House on Tuesday, the 22nd day of January, at 11 o'clock A. M.
The Henrico Troop will meet at the same time and place, in citizens' dress, without arms.
ja 18--4t J. Lucius Davis, Col. 33rd Reg't.

25 Bbls. and 25 half bbls.
Beveridge Ale, in store and for sale by [ja 9] Wm. Taylor.

div3.head: By J. H. Digges, Auct'r.
div3.p:
Library of the late Judge P. V. Daniel to be sold at Auction, by Catalogue, on Monday afternoon, at 4 O'Clock, Jan. 28TH, at Auction Room 86 Main St., consisting of rare and valuable law and Miscellaneous Works, which have been kept in good order, and are worthy the attention of every one wishing to make valuable additions to their libraries.
Messrs. West & Johnston at 145 Main street, will attend to buying for parties unable to attend the sale.
Catalogues now ready and to be had at the auction room and West & Johnston's Bookstore.
Also, at the same time, will be sold, to cover advances--
1 set Prescott's Mexico, 3 vols.
1 set Prescott's Peru, 2 vols.
1 set Irving's Works, 16 vols.
1 set Irving's Washington, 5 vols.
Half-hours with best Authors, 2 vols.
MacAULAYulay's Essays, 5 vols.
MacAULAYulay's Sketches, 1 vols.
EncyclopŒDia Amer, Literature, 2 vols.
English Edition Shakespeare, 10 vols.
Tupper's Works, 1 vol.
The above Books are all in good order, and bound in half-calf binding, and will be sold without reserve.

Terms.--Cash.
J. H. Digges, Auct'r.

D. F. Booth, Salesman.

438 bbls. choice N. O. Molasses.

Also — A large lot of ready-made Clothing, Dry Goods, Shoes, &c.; Merino Shirts, Drawers, Socks, Blankets, Hoop Skirts, &c.

Taliaferro, on Main street, in Sidney, near the Old Fair Grounds, all the Household and Kitchen Furniture, consisting in part of one very superior Rosewood case, 7-octave Piano, Stool and Cover; Rosewood Parlor Sofas and Chairs, in brocatelle; Rosewood Marble-Top Table; one Etagere; Mahogany Bedsteads, Bureau, Washstands, Marble-tops; Feather Beds, Hair, and Shuck Mattresses, Sideboard, Extension Dining Table, Chairs, Wardrobes, Carpets, China and Glassware, Cooking Stove, &c.; with the usual assortment of Kitchen Furniture. div3.head: Dental Notice.
div3.p:
--The co-partnership of Hudson & Davison is this day dissolved by mutual consent, F. Davison retiring from the office on the 1st day of February next, and R. N.Hudson taking possession of it himself.
All the accounts due the office will be placed in the hands of Messrs. Redwood & Keach for collection, who alone are authorized to receipt for the same.
R. N. Hudson, Dentists.
F. Davison, Dentists.
Richmond, Jan. 18, 1861. ja 19--3t*

N. B.--Dr. Davison can be found after the first of February at his own office, in Corinthian Hall, a few doors above.
ja 21--2t*

div3.head: Co-partnership.
div3.p:
--I have this day associated with me in the Manufacturing Tobacco Business, my son, P. H.Mayo.
The style of the firm will be Ro. A. & P. H. Mayo.
Ro. A. Mayo.
Richmond, January 1, 1861. ja 15--6t*

div3.head: Dissolution.
div3.p: --The firm of Sublett & Smith is this day dissolved by mutual consent, John A. Smith having sold out his interest in the books of the concern to John G. Powell.
P. B. Sublett,
John A. Smith.

Having formed a Co-Partnership, under the style of Powell & Sublett, for the purpose of conducting the Commission and Forwarding Business, in the city of Richmond, we respectfully offer our services to the planters of Virginia and North Carolina, for the sale of all kinds of country Produce, and for the forwarding of Merchandize and Manufactured Tobacco, feeling confident, from our past experience in the business, of our ability to protect the interests of our patrons.
John G. Powell,
P. B. Sublett.

A Card,--In tendering my sincere thanks to my friends for the very liberal patronage bestowed upon me for the last three years, I would most respectfully solicit a continuance of their favors, and of the public generally, for the new concern, pledging myself, as heretofore, to give strict personal attention to all business entrusted to us, and to use every effort to promote their interest.
John G. Powell.

In retiring from the firm of Sublett & Smith, I return my thanks to my friends for the favors bestowed on me, and can confidently recommend my successor and former associate to them as gentlemen worthy of their patronage, and well calculated to advance their interest.
John A. Smith.
January 1, 1861. ja 2--law4w

div3.head: Dissolution of Co-partnership.
div3.p:
In consequence of the decease of our senior partner, the firms of N. M. Martin, Brother & Co., Petersburg, and N. M. Martin, son & Co., Richmond, cease from this date, and are dissolved.
Either of the surviving partners is authorized to close the business.
Robert A. Martin, Surviving Partners.
Walter K. Martin, Surviving Partners.
Robt. Tannahill, Surviving Partners.
N. M. Martin, Jr., Surviving Partners.
R. H. Cunningham, Jr., Surviving Partners.

New Co-Partnership.--The undersigned have entered into partnership, and will continue the Grocery and Commission Business, in Petersburg, under the firm of Martin, Tannahill & Co., and the General Commission Business in Richmond, under the style of Walter K. Martin & Co.

We take this occasion to return our sincere thanks to our numerous friends for the liberal confidence and support extended to the late firms of N. M. Martin, Brother & Co., Petersburg, and N. M. Martin, son & Co., Richmond, and hope, by our best personal exertions, to merit a continuance of the same.
Robert A. Martin,
Walter K. Martin,
Robt. Tannahill,
M. M. Martin, Jr.,
Resident Partners:

p.hi: Robert A. Martin, Walter K. Martin,

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p:
--The Co-partnership heretofore existing between the undersigned is this day dissolved by mutual consent.
The affairs of the concern will be settled by Wm. B. Isaacs, who is authorized to use the name of the firm for that purpose.
Joseph Brummel,
Wm. B. Isaacs,
Wm. F. Taylor.
Richmond, 1st January, 1861.

The undersigned will continue the Exchange and Banking Business of the late firm of Isaacs & Taylor.
It will be conducted under the style and firm of Wm. B. Isaacs & Co., B. H. Smith, Jr., having an interest therein.
1st January, 1861, Wm. B. Isaacs.

In withdrawing from the Exchange and Banking Business, we feel it due to our successor to say that, from a long personal acquaintance and business connection with him, we have every confidence in his means, ability, integrity and prudence in the management of his affairs, and do most cordially recommend him to our friends and the public as every way worthy of their confidence and patronage.
Joseph Brummel,
ja 1--1m Wm. F. Taylor.

div3.head: Co-partnership.
div3.p:
--I have this day associated with me in the Commission Business, Mr. Rodolph King, who has for some years been in my employment.
The business will hereafter be conducted under the style of L. Waller & Co. Returning my thanks for the very liberal patronage heretofore bestowed on me, I respectfully solicit a continuance of the same for the new concern.
[ja 1 --d&cw1m] L. Waller.

the firm of Jones & Co. having dissolved, I shall continue to carry on business at the same place, No. 8 Main street, where will always be found a large stock of fine imported and domestic Liquors, Provisions and Groceries, of all kinds, which will be sold on reasonable terms, to which I invite the attention of the trade generally.
Thomas Jones.
January 1st, 1861. ja 1--1m

div3.head: Richmond arms Manufactory.
div3.p: --The subscriber having determined to manufacture in this city an improved Rifle, invented by Mr. N. L. Babcock, would respectfully invite those who may desire to procure arms, either for individual or Company purposes, to examine the proposed Rifle, a specimen of which can be seen at my Iron Railing Manufactory, on 9th street, next to the Virginia Mechanics' Institute, and where orders will be received.
ja 17--1w Jas. D. Browne.
just received and for sale low, a complete assortment of Colt's, Sharpe's, Smith & Wesson's, and other Revolvers.
A call is solicited from those in want of anything in the Gun way. T. W. Tignor,
Gun Maker, Main st., below the Market.
50 Hhds. fair to choice New Orleans Sugar, for sale by

div3.head: By Goddin & Apperson, Auct's.
div3.p:
Trustee's sale of valuable Farm of 300 Acres, in Chesterfield County, four miles from Manchester. --As trustee in a certain deed of trust, from Mr. Jasper S. Clayton, dated 1st January, 1860, duly recorded in Chesterfield County Court, I shall, in exception thereof, proceed to sell at public auction, on the premises, on Monday, the 4th February, 1861, at 12 o'clock M., (if fair; if not the first fair day thereafter,) the valuable farm formerly owned by Mr. Jesse Whitehead, and now occupied by Mr. Clayton.
The tract contains 300 acres. The place is so well known that a further description is deemed unnecessary.

Terms.--Enough in cash to defray expenses of sale, and to discharge a note of $1,323.33, with interest; on a credit as to $1,323.33 until 1st January, 1862; on a credit as to $1,323.33 until 1st January, 1863--with interest from 1st January, 1860--and balance on such terms of credit as may be announced at the time of sale.
The taxes for 1861 to be paid by the purchaser.

ja 12 Augustus Bodeker.
Trustee.

div3.head: By E. B. Cook, Auctioneer.
div3.p: sale of personal property in New Kent County, on the Richmond and York River Railroad, at Auction.--On Tuesday, 29th inst., at 10 o'clock, I will sell at the farm of R. L. Walker, Esq., situated in New Kent county, on the Richmond and York River Railroad, 13 miles below Richmond, the following personal property, viz:

6 Young Mules, 1 young Mare, 1 pair very fine young Match Horses, 1 Horse, 2 Milch Cows, 9 Oxen, 25 Stock Hogs — improved breeds; an elegant set of Farming Implements, amongst them one of Beckford & Hoffman's Wheat Drills

The Household Furniture, consisting of--1 Elegant Piano, 2 fine Sofas, Parlor Etagere, Centre Table, Chairs, Hat Rack, Black Walnut Extension Dining Tables, 1 very fine Marble-Top Sideboard, with Etagere; Book Case; 2 sets Chamber Furniture--one of Black Walnut, very costly; the other plain — together with Feather Beds, Mattresses, and various other articles in the housekeeping line too numerous to mention.
Terms.--All sums under $100, cash; over $100 and under $250, sixty days; over $250, four months credit, for approved, negotiable paper.
ja 15 E. B. Cook, Auct.

250 cases Boots, Shoes and Hats.
ja 15 I. & G. B. Davenport, Aucts.

div3.head: Pure Imported Champagne Wine at Auction.--
div3.p: On Tuesday, 29th of Jan., we will sell, at 10 o'clock, at our auction store, 200 cases, 150 baskets, quarts and pints pure
Imported Champagne Wine.
ja 15 I. & G. B. Davenport, Aucts.

div3.head: To the public.
div3.p:
--In consequence of having received an appointment to the Presidency of "Quincy Academy," at Quincy, Florida, the Rev. R. F. Stubbs will resign his post in the Union Female Collegiate Institute, on the 1st of February next.
The Chair thus vacated will be filled by the appointment of Mr. Leonidas points, A. B., a graduate of the University of Virginia.

It being reported that this Institute will close on the 1st of February, 1 take this occasion to correct this mistake.
I have no intention of that kind whatever, and still solicit a share of the patronage of the citizens of Richmond and vicinity.
W. J. Points, M. D.,
ja 12--eodtF1 Principal.

div3.head: English and Classical School, Mayo street.
div3.p:
C. P. Burrus would be pleased to receive a few additional pupils, to fill vacancies which have occurred in his School.
ja 12--12t*

div3.head: School at Meadow Farm, Hanover.
div3.p: --The exercises of this School, under the immediate instruction of Mr. John K. Starke, who has been successfully engaged in teaching for several years, will be resumed on the 15th instant, and continue ten months, with one month's vacation in midsummer.
Terms.--For Board and Tuition, to be paid half-annually, $130.
ja 9--dlw&3tawtFeb1st W. B. Sydnor.

div3.head: Laurel Spring Academy.
div3.p:
--Having employed a competent teacher, I would like to take three or four young ladies, from 10 to 15 years of age. The terms are very moderate.
For English, French, Latin and Music, including board, lodging and washing, $200. James L. Ege.
ja 4--1m* One and a half miles from the city.

Also, Red Ash, Egg and Stove prepared Anthracite Coal of superior quality.
Albert Blair, office 14th st.,
ja 18--3t* Near Mayo's Bridge.
--The prices of Carbon Hill Coke will be until further notice, as follows;
Lump Coke...$6,00 per load.
Stove Coke...5.50 per load.
